posts.commentary: Thanks for sharing, Aaron! 100% agree with your thought leadership here.

actor.name: Karl Simon
actor.position: Founder & Chief Technology Officer @ Subatomic

posts.commentary:
Absolutely, AI Agents‚Äô are evolving their role in enterprises, these changes are unfolding with increasing depth. AI Agents now go beyond automation, breaking down silos and enabling cross-functional collaboration that reshapes workflows and organizational structures. 

A key maturity is the recognition that workflows must be optimized before AI integration, avoiding common pitfalls and enabling long-term success. Interoperability remains essential‚Äîno single AI agent covers all needs, so seamless communication and integration across diverse systems is a must. 

Crucially, workforce readiness stands out as a fundamental pillar. Real transformation happens when employees evolve alongside AI, collaborating with agents rather than competing with them. Together, these forces herald a new era of agile, integrated, and innovative enterprises empowered by AI Agents.

That's why, out solutions at Kanerika Inc specialize in building enterprise-grade AI Agents that integrate seamlessly across complex workflows, helping organizations unlock new levels of productivity and collaboration.

actor.name: Bhupendra Chopra
actor.position: 100+ Businesses Transformed with Data and AI/ML | CRO - Kanerika | Ex -Informatica, Oracle, TCS

posts.commentary: Insightful summary! We're seeing similar trends in government ERP projects‚ÄîAI demands are high, but without disciplined workflows and inter-system interoperability, adoption lags. Clean process design and cross-functional collaboration are becoming just as critical as the tech itself. Change management is the real game-changer here

actor.name: Mukul Soni
actor.position: Empowering Businesses with ERP Solutions | Specialized in E-Governance & Enterprise ERP | Founder - B2Grow

posts.commentary:
The (legacy) workflow struggle is real: 

I. There is the process as designed or stated/defined v1.0.

II. Then there is the business' self knowledge that presents v1.1 or v1.2 or v1.3 under known conditions / scenarios. Acknowledged Variants.

III. Then there is real life and the process map or workflow that emerges from tracing data points presents loads more variants and exceptions. 

Not for every workflow, but many. 

Lots to describe, depict, navigate, measure & verify, then  un-wind to define clearly and move forward again. 

What's worse, it's a brownfield conversation usually with tribal insights and tech debt cluttering it in the modern enterprise instead of a cleansheet/greenfield/startup decision point.

actor.name: Evan Kirstel
actor.position: CreateüìùPublishüóûÔ∏èAmplifyüì£ TechInfluencer, Analyst, Content Creator w/600K Social Media followers, Deep Expertise in Enterprise üíª Cloud ‚òÅÔ∏è5G üì°AI ü§ñTelecom ‚òéÔ∏è CX üîë Cyber üè• DigitalHealth. TwitterX @evankirstel

posts.content:
Hosted a dinner with about 15 IT leaders around the future of AI Agents in the enterprise. Here are a few updates on the state of the world at least at some large enterprises:

* For many organizations, the demand from the business for AI is continuing outstrip the ability to implement the technology. This is super relevant because we‚Äôre already 2.5 years after the ChatGPT moment and there‚Äôs really no slow down in use cases.

* AI is causing more department lines to collapse or blur. Companies are finding that teams can now begin to do more of the work of their adjacent functions, which clearly will have some very interesting implications to corporate org structures in the future.

* Getting workflows well understood before you add AI Agents to them continues to be a hot topic. If you don‚Äôt have a clean process today, it‚Äôs very hard to bring automation to that work, so many companies are using AI as an opportunity to bring more discipline to the workflows. 

* AI Agent interoperability remains a continued focus for IT leaders. It‚Äôs obvious that no singular system can handle all the agentic workflows across the enterprise, which means having AI systems talk to each other is still a huge focus.

* Training of the next generation workforce remains a huge focus. It‚Äôs clear that everyone believes the next generation will work way faster, but there remains some concern on how this new workforce can fully learn the ropes of the business without having to ‚Äúdo the work‚Äù now.

Overall, momentum remains very strong for AI Agents in the enterprise, and at the same time it‚Äôs clear that there will be years of change management ahead to fully deploy agents across the enterprise.

author.name: Aaron Levie
author.info: CEO at Box - Intelligent Content Management

actor.name: Keegan Longueira
actor.position: Growth Specialist Hubspot | Passionate about Revenue Operations for Marketing and Sales Teams - All things health, fitness and adventureüèãÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üèÉüóª

posts.content:
For decades, career growth followed a familiar formula:
More headcount. More budget. More scope.¬†
That model is changing.

In the AI era, careers won‚Äôt be built on span of control, they‚Äôll be built on innovation density.

Today, anyone - from ICs to execs - can scale their impact without more headcount, more budget, or more time. The playing field is flatter. The differentiator? How fast you can learn, apply, and compound innovation with AI.

If you‚Äôre thinking about career growth, stop asking: ‚ÄúHow can I get more?‚Äù
Start asking: ‚ÄúHow can I innovate more with AI?‚Äù

The people who rise fast will:

See problems through an AI-first lens.
Move from manual to scalable.
Iterate faster than the rest.

Your team size won‚Äôt define your trajectory.
Your creativity will.
Your budget won‚Äôt signal your value.
Your innovation density will.

actor.name: Sidheshwar S Chauhan
actor.position: Global MarTech & Digital Transformation Leader | Fortune 500 Advisor | MarTech & CX Executive | AI-Powered CX Innovator | $200M+ Revenue Impact | Adobe Experience Cloud Expert | Helping Brands Humanize Digital

posts.commentary: Interesting idea, Scott, but are those stable environments really so stable? According to you, the martech universe grew from a few hundred vendors/products in 2011 to almost 10,000 in a dozen years, with many new categories and capabilities. Today AI not only powers thousands of new products but adds profound capabilities to existing products. And AI's capabilities are growing at an astonishing speed - witness Microsoft reporting at least a quarter of its code now being written by AI, the Kalshi ad during the NBA finals (by Google Veo), and the lengthy analyses and reports generated by AI, prompting consulting firms to lay off significant parts of new hires before they even start. We seem to be on the handle of the hockey stick.

actor.name: Louis Gudema
actor.position: Building brands and generating leads for B2B startups and SMBs as fractional head of marketing. Award-winning author and experienced mentor of MIT startups. Expert witness on startups and marketing.

posts.commentary: Great perspective, Scott.

actor.name: David M Wallace
actor.position: Executive Advisor, Customer Data and Analytics

posts.commentary:
good way to visualize things. 

Although "stable" might be a bit of a reach.  I'm yet to meet a marketer/marketing-ops who's in 'smooth sailing' mode.  

Most environments never quite stabilize (perhaps due to minor disruptions from staff change, vendor switch outs, feature updates, etc.).  NEver a dull moment!

actor.name: Roger Beharry Lall
actor.position: VP Marketing/Product Strategist turned Industry Analyst & Board Director. Excited about Category Creation | Martech/Adtech Trends | Go-to-market strategy | Market Analysis | Innovation

posts.commentary:
Yes...but was digital marketing ever "stable?" I suppose parts of it were. Search leaps to mind. Talk about a cash cow on all sides. For 25 years. The rest of digital marketing? You could make the case it's been never-ending scope creep with no particular format, medium, strategy, tactic, tool, or platform being particular stable over the last quarter century. Everything turned into an arb; the marketing equivalent of high-frequency trading as digital transformation meant that change could proliferate sometimes in months (even weeks) where it once took decades.

No question AI is a disruption and I don't disagree with the grouping you're using. But your graphic has me thinking about exactly what it is that AI is disrupting...

Robots aren't coming. They're already here.

EngineAI just dropped a demo of its $12,000 PM01 humanoid jogging alongside a human and landing backflips.

Key features include:

‚Üí Dimensions: 4.5 feet tall, weighs 88 lbs
‚Üí Mobility: 24 degrees of freedom (DoF)
‚Üí Flexibility: 320¬∞ waist rotation
‚Üí Speed: Up to 4.4 mph
‚Üí Battery Life: Up to 2 hours
‚Üí Hardware: Intel N97, NVIDIA Jetson Orin

The humanoid race is heating up with Tesla, Agility, Figure, 1X and now Engine pushing the limits.

actor.name: Robert Owen
actor.position: Owner, Happy Earth Publishing

posts.content:
BREAKING: The U.S. Copyright Office just dropped a major update on AI-generated content.

Here are the key takeaways:

‚Üí AI-Generated = Not Copyrightable
If AI fully generates the content, you don‚Äôt own it. That "stunning" Midjourney image? Legally, it's up for grabs.

‚Üí Prompts ‚â† Authorship
Typing "a majestic space lion" doesn‚Äôt make you an artist. Copyright requires real human creativity, not just good AI instructions.

‚Üí Human Creativity = Copyrightable
If you edit, arrange, or remix AI content, your contributions can be protected. But how much human input is enough? That's still a gray area.

‚Üí No New Laws.. Yet
The Copyright Office says existing laws are fine for now, but with AI evolving fast, this debate is far from over.

What does everyone think about this? üìú

postedAt.postedAgoText: 7 months ago ‚Ä¢ Visible to anyone on or off LinkedIn
